#print(objs)

for n in range(0,int(num)+1):
 exec("objs[" + str(n) + "].location.x = 0")
 exec("objs[" + str(n) + "].location.y = 0")
 exec("objs[" + str(n) + "].location.z = 0")
 exec("objs[" + str(n) + "].rotation_euler.x = 0")
 exec("objs[" + str(n) + "].rotation_euler.y = 0")
 exec("objs[" + str(n) + "].rotation_euler.z = 0")
 exec("objs[" + str(n) + "].scale.x = 1")
 exec("objs[" + str(n) + "].scale.y = 1")
 exec("objs[" + str(n) + "].scale.z = 1")

acs = []
n=-1
for obj in objs:
 n=n+1
 for other in bpy.data.objects:
  other.select_set(False)
 objs[n].select_set(True)    
 bpy.context.view_layer.objects.active = objs[n]

 acname = "o"+str(n)+"action"+str(KMVAR_time)
 acs.append(bpy.data.actions.new(acname))

locX=[]
locY=[]
locZ=[]
rotX=[]
rotY=[]
rotZ=[]
scaleX=[]
scaleY=[]
scaleZ=[]
n=-1
for obj in objs:
 n=n+1
 for other in bpy.data.objects:
  other.select_set(False)
 objs[n].select_set(True)    
 bpy.context.view_layer.objects.active = objs[n]
 locX.append(acs[n].fcurves.new(data_path="location",index=0))
 locY.append(acs[n].fcurves.new(data_path="location",index=1))
 locZ.append(acs[n].fcurves.new(data_path="location",index=2))
 rotX.append(acs[n].fcurves.new(data_path="rotation_euler",index=0))
 rotY.append(acs[n].fcurves.new(data_path="rotation_euler",index=1))
 rotZ.append(acs[n].fcurves.new(data_path="rotation_euler",index=2))
 scaleX.append(acs[n].fcurves.new(data_path="scale",index=0))
 scaleY.append(acs[n].fcurves.new(data_path="scale",index=1))
 scaleZ.append(acs[n].fcurves.new(data_path="scale",index=2))
print("locX should contain 2 fcurves:" +str(locX))



#so now we have lists of 2, for example, locX is now a list containing 2 f-curves. for obj 0 and 1

#this makes it work for 1. but you need to make it work for 2. in the below example, there already exists an fcurve for each one of those names in the list. those are a variable name, which is an fcurve. but now, instead, there are lists of 2. What this originally did was, it adds 2 keyframes (A and B) to each fcurve.  Now i've indented the whole thing, and it's going to run through twice. wherever you would see "locX" the set, it needs to be "locX[n]", and wherever it is used to invoke the variable "AlocX", it needs to instead be "o"+str(n)+"AlocX". done√


print("locX set="+str(n))
n=-1
for obj in objs:
 n=n+1
 for other in bpy.data.objects:
  other.select_set(False)
 objs[n].select_set(True)    
 bpy.context.view_layer.objects.active = objs[n]


 fnames=["locX","locY","locZ","rotX","rotY","rotZ","scaleX","scaleY","scaleZ"]
 for fname in fnames:
  exec("Aco=o" + str(n) + "A"+str(fname))
  exec("Bco=o" + str(n) + "B"+str(fname))
  exec("f="+str(fname)+"[" + str(n) + "]")
  f.keyframe_points.add(2)
  f.keyframe_points[0].co = (1,float(Aco))
  f.keyframe_points[1].co = (61,float(Bco))
  f.keyframe_points[0].interpolation = 'LINEAR'
  f.keyframe_points[1].interpolation = 'LINEAR'

for n in range(0,int(num)+1):

 exec("objs[" + str(n) + "].location.y = 0")

 bpy.ops.constraint.move_up(my_context, constraint=str(acconname), owner='OBJECT')

html: 4.9.20  1:49 pm   what has writing/producing those really short (<= 10 seconds) songs done for you? I'm doing that now because I am really bad at developing a melody but really good at coming up with a short melodic phrase and producing it to sound really fun and interesting. I think it is making me better somehow. I would also like to know how you learned to create longer songs that develop the melody and go to other places. It's hard for me to write stuff that doesn't "end" as quickly as it started.
original_html: 4.9.20  1:49 pm   what has writing/producing those really short (<= 10 seconds) songs done for you? I'm doing that now because I am really bad at developing a melody but really good at coming up with a short melodic phrase and producing it to sound really fun and interesting. I think it is making me better somehow. I would also like to know how you learned to create longer songs that develop the melody and go to other places. It's hard for me to write stuff that doesn't "end" as quickly as it started.
